headline.main: The Big City; Legislating A Childhood Without Risk

docs.abstract: John Tierney The Big City column deplores overprotectiveness of baby boomers toward their children, and cites two New York City Council regulations passed this week; one prohibits smoking in all areas of restaurants and another forces children to wear helmets while riding scooters; contends that these laws make parents feel safer and politicians look virtuous (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: THE City Council has been busy caring for everyone else's children this week. It voted unanimously to make them wear helmets when riding scooters, and the Council speaker, Peter F. Vallone, defended his proposed new smoking restrictions in restaurants by saying, ''My concern here is basically for children and the health effects of smoking.'' Devotion to children is a wonderful thing, but it can seem a little too wonderful when proclaimed by politicians. Children, after all, are not eligible to vote. When politicians start talking about laws to protect kids, the first question to ask is: which adults are going to benefit?

docs.abstract: Proposal to expand New York City smoking restrictions, introduced in legislation by City Council Speaker Peter F Vallone, provokes criticism from Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani and representatives of city's restaurant industry; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: A proposal to expand New York City smoking restrictions, introduced yesterday in legislation by the City Council speaker, Peter F. Vallone, provoked criticism yesterday from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and representatives of the city's restaurant industry, who said it would give the government too much control over personal decisions. The changes sought by Mr. Vallone, a Democratic candidate for mayor, would all but eliminate smoking in restaurants, regardless of their size or the barriers separating dining rooms from bar areas. It would strengthen a 1995 law that prohibited smoking in restaurants with more than 35 seats, except in bar areas.
